questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless lump on her neck. She says that the lump has gradually increased in size and is hard to the touch. Family history is unremarkable. She appears healthy. Examination shows a 2.5-cm (1-in) firm, irregular swelling on the left side of the neck that moves with swallowing. There is painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound of the neck shows a solitary left lobe thyroid mass with increased vascularity and hyperechogenic punctate regions. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is scheduled for the upcoming week. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Hurthle cell carcinoma of the thyroid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Follicular carcinoma is the second most common type of thyroid cancer (10% of all cases) with a peak incidence of 40–60 years of age. Follicular carcinoma is unique in that it spreads predominantly via the bloodstream to the lungs and bones. In this patient with cervical lymphadenopathy, a more common type of thyroid cancer that metastasizes to the lymph nodes is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Medullary carcinoma is a rare type of cancer (< 10% of all thyroid cancers) that is more likely to occur in individuals 50–60 years of age or in association with MEN II syndromes. This patient is 36 years old, has palpable lymph nodes, and a negative family history, which all suggest a more common type of thyroid cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Hurthle cell carcinomas are relatively rare tumors of the thyroid (3% of all cases) that are most likely to occur in patients between 50–60 years of age. Hurthle cell carcinoma mainly spreads hematogenously, although lymph node metastasis is not uncommon. The most likely diagnosis in this 36-year-old patient with painless cervical lymphadenopathy is a more common thyroid cancer that spreads to the lymph nodes.

D) CORRECT:

Papillary thyroid carcinomas are the most common type of thyroid cancer (∼ 80% of cases) and have a peak incidence between 30–50 years of age. These carcinomas commonly manifest with early lymphatic spread. Patients often present with painless cervical lymphadenopathy that may be detectable before the primary tumor. The hyperechogenic punctate regions seen on this patient's ultrasound likely represent microcalcifications, another characteristic feature of this type of thyroid cancer. Based on the overall incidence rate, affected age group, and metastatic pattern, papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

See “Characteristic features of thyroid cancer” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Anaplastic carcinoma is a rare and highly aggressive cancer of the thyroid (1–2% of cases) that typically spreads early via the lymphatic system, which could explain the new-onset lymphadenopathy in this patient. However, anaplastic carcinoma typically affects patients older than 60 years of age. In this 36-year-old patient with a relatively slow-growing thyroid mass, another type of thyroid cancer is more likely.
questions.hint: A thyroid mass with features of malignancy (increased vascularity and hyperechogenic punctate areas) and painless cervical lymphadenopathy are suggestive of a specific type of thyroid cancer.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a small lump on the right side of her neck that she noticed while putting lotion on 1 week ago. She has not had any weight change, palpitations, or altered bowel habits. There is no family history of serious illness. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last for 4 days. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Examination shows a small nodule on the right side of the neck that moves with swallowing. There is no lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasound of the neck shows a 0.9-cm (0.35-in) right lobe thyroid mass with microcalcifications and irregular margins. Which of the following is most likely to be helpful in determining the next step in management?

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the swelling

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy is indicated when malignancy is suspected in a thyroid nodule. Although this patient's ultrasound findings (e.g., a mass with microcalcifications and irregular margins) raise suspicion for malignancy, a different assessment is more helpful to determine whether FNA is warranted at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

An open biopsy can be used to remove the complete thyroid nodule or to obtain a better sample if fine-needle aspiration biopsy fails to provide clear results (e.g., because of an insufficient sample size). An open biopsy is not the most appropriate initial assessment.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy allows for classification of thyroid nodules based on the amount of radiotracer a nodule absorbs and is able to distinguish between hot and cold nodules. Although thyroid scintigraphy may be performed in the workup of thyroid nodules, a more basic functional assessment of the thyroid gland should be conducted first.

A hot or hyperfunctioning nodule contains thyroid hormone-producing cells and could result in hyperthyroidism, whereas a cold or nonfunctional nodule lacks thyroid hormone-producing cells and may indicate malignant neoplasia.

D) CORRECT:

Measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) serum concentration and thyroid ultrasound should be performed in all patients with a suspected thyroid nodule to determine further management. If TSH levels are normal or elevated, this patient should undergo regular monitoring in case the tumor grows to ≥ 1 cm, in which case fine-needle aspiration biopsy would be indicated because of her suspicious ultrasound findings (i.e., a mass with microcalcifications and irregular margins). If TSH levels are subnormal, she should be evaluated for hyperthyroidism with thyroid scintigraphy.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

E) INCORRECT:

Although a CT scan of the neck is recommended for the staging of confirmed thyroid cancer, it is not suitable for the initial evaluation of patients with a thyroid nodule.
questions.hint: Thyroid function has not yet been assessed in this patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician with a lump on her throat that has steadily increased in size over the past 5 months. She does not have difficulties swallowing, dyspnea, or changes in voice. Examination shows a 3-cm, hard swelling on the left side of her neck that moves with swallowing. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Thyroid functions tests are within the reference range. Ultrasound of the neck shows an irregular, hypoechogenic mass in the left lobe of the thyroid. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is inconclusive. The surgeon and patient agree that the most appropriate next step is a diagnostic lobectomy and isthmectomy. Surgery shows a 3.5-cm gray tan thyroid tumor with invasion of surrounding blood vessels, including the veins. The specimen is sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on microscopic examination of the mass?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Undifferentiated giant cells are characteristic of anaplastic thyroid cancer. This type of tumor, while it may demonstrate vascular invasion, is a rare type of thyroid cancer (1–2% of cases) and would be less likely in a patient younger than 60 years of age. Additionally, anaplastic thyroid cancer would most likely manifest as a rapidly growing thyroid mass with neck pain, dysphagia, dyspnea, or hoarseness.

B) CORRECT:

Capsular and blood vessel invasion and uniform follicles are characteristic histopathologic findings of follicular thyroid cancer, the second most common type of thyroid cancer after papillary thyroid cancer. Follicular thyroid cancer is characterized by hematogenous spread (most commonly to the lungs and bones) and lymph node involvement is rare.

Further treatment in this patient will likely involve total thyroidectomy, possibly followed by radioiodine therapy. Afterward, thyroid hormone replacement therapy (i.e., levothyroxine) in the highest possible dose (according to the patient's tolerance) will be initiated to suppress TSH and thus reduce the risk of stimulating remaining malignant tissue.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a thyroid tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

A partly encapsulated (capsule marked by hatched blue overlay) thyroid lesion comprised of follicles of varying size and shape (blue overlay) can be seen. Focally, this lesion displays a capsular invasion (yellow overlay), which is diagnostic of follicular thyroid carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Psammoma bodies suggest papillary thyroid cancer. Although papillary thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid malignancy, and this patient does belong to the peak incidence age group (30–50 years), it does not cause invasion of surrounding vascular structures.
Image Description:

Histopathology slide of the ovary (H&E stain)

In addition to papillary tumor cells, there are two Psammoma bodies located in the lower left corner of the image (red overlay). Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellar calcifications, which are characteristic for serous tumors of the ovary.

D) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of atypical lymphoid tissue in the thyroid suggests a thyroid lymphoma (an unusual manifestation of non-Hodgkin lymphoma). Thyroid lymphoma is rather rare (∼ 2% of malignant thyroid tumors) and usually arises in patients with preexisting Hashimoto thyroiditis (clinically characterized by fatigue, constipation, weight gain, and other hypothyroidism-related features). Additionally, thyroid lymphoma would most likely manifest as a rapidly growing thyroid mass with dysphagia, dyspnea, or hoarseness.

E) INCORRECT:

Orphan Annie eyes nuclei (large nuclei with a cleared-out appearance in the center and chromatin in the periphery) suggest papillary thyroid cancer. Although papillary thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid malignancy, and this patient does belong to the peak incidence age group (30–50 years), it typically does not cause invasion of surrounding vascular structures.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a thyroid tumor tissue sample (H&E stain; high magnification)

Cells arranged in a papillary architecture are visible (examples indicated by green overlay). Some cell nuclei appear invaginated (nuclear grooves), giving them a coffee-bean appearance (examples indicated by white lines). The nuclei in general show pale staining centrally and powdery chromatin in the periphery (Orphan Annie-eye nuclei; example highlighted by red overlay).

These nuclear changes in a thyroid tumor with papillary architecture confirm the diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma.
questions.hint: Invasion of surrounding vascular structures by the tumor suggests follicular thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up visit after she had a PET scan that showed a nodule on the thyroid gland. She has no difficulty or pain while swallowing. She was treated for non-Hodgkin lymphoma at 28 years of age, which included external beam radiation to the head and neck and four cycles of chemotherapy. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Glucose
82 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.7 mg/dL


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
3 μU/mL


Ultrasound of the neck shows a 1.2-cm (0.5-in) nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid with irregular margins and microcalcifications. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy shows Psammoma bodies and cells with clear, ground-glass, empty nuclei. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Generally, well-differentiated thyroid cancers such as papillary microcarcinomas are not treated with percutaneous radiotherapy because this approach does not work as well as radioiodine treatment and does not target thyroid tissue as selectively, posing a risk to nearby structures in the head and neck. Poorly differentiated thyroid cancers (medullary and anaplastic) may be treated with percutaneous radiotherapy because they do not respond to radioiodine therapy. These cancers more often manifest with metastases and would have fine-needle aspiration findings showing C cells or multinucleated giant cells with spindles.

B) INCORRECT:

Radioiodine therapy is a common adjunct treatment option for well-differentiated thyroid cancers (e.g., papillary carcinoma), as the malignant cells take up iodine, resulting in ablation. However, radioiodine therapy is an adjuvant treatment for papillary carcinoma and is not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient. Radioablative treatments may be used later if there is reason to suspect remaining thyroid tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation and follow-up would be appropriate for benign nodules. In the case of malignant tumors such as this patient's 1.2-cm nodule, a delay in treatment is not recommended, as the tumor is likely to grow. Papillary carcinomas greater than 1.0-cm are associated with an increased risk of spread to bilateral thyroid lobes, extrathyroidal invasion, and lymph node metastases. Early identification greatly improves outcomes but only if an appropriate course of treatment is begun immediately.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy is performed as part of the workup for a thyroid nodule in the setting of low TSH, the evaluation of ectopic thyroid tissue, or the evaluation of retrosternal goiter. This patient has none of these indications and has already undergone a fine-needle aspiration biopsy that confirmed papillary carcinoma. Therefore, thyroid scintigraphy is not indicated for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical nodule excision with the intent to preserve functional (i.e., hormone-producing) tissue is a common approach in many malignancies. However, nodule excision is not recommended in patients with thyroid cancer because malignant cells may be present outside of the nodule, posing a risk for recurrence and metastasis. A different treatment approach that is more effective in removing all malignant tissue is indicated in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Total thyroidectomy is an effective treatment option for most thyroid cancers, including well-differentiated thyroid carcinomas such as papillary carcinoma. Papillary thyroid cancer is more common in women than men, and prior exposure to radiation (particularly during childhood) is an environmental risk factor. Small papillary microcarcinomas (< 1.0 cm, no affected lymph nodes, no metastases) can be treated with a partial resection (hemithyroidectomy). This patient's history of external beam radiation to the head and neck region is a contraindication for hemithyroidectomy because of the risk of recurrence in the contralateral thyroid lobe.

Neck dissection should be considered for advanced papillary carcinoma with extrathyroidal spread, even when there is no clinical suspicion of nodal metastasis.
Image Description:

Ultrasound thyroid (longitudinal plane)

A solid nodule in the upper pole has ill-defined margins and contains multiple microcalcifications.

The presence of microcalcifications increases suspicion for malignancy
questions.hint: Fine-needle aspiration findings of Psammoma bodies and “Orphan Annie” nuclei (clear, ground-glass, empty nuclei) in a thyroid nodule indicate a papillary microcarcinoma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a lump on her neck. The lump is mildly painful. She appears healthy. Examination shows a swelling on the left side of her neck that moves on swallowing. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Her TSH is 3.6 μU/mL. Ultrasound shows a 0.4-cm (0.15-in) hypoechoic mass in the left thyroid lobe. Fine-needle aspiration of the mass shows neoplastic follicular cells. Molecular analysis of the aspirate shows a mutation in the RAS gene. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapy drugs such as doxorubicin and lenvatinib are approved for thyroid cancers that are poorly differentiated, recurrent, or refractory to other standard treatments. Because this patient's FNA findings are concerning for well-differentiated thyroid cancer, she should receive standard first-line management.

B) INCORRECT:

Watchful waiting is not appropriate in a patient with an FNA that is concerning for well-differentiated thyroid cancer. Treatment delays may lead to cancer growth and invasion into the surrounding structures. This patient, therefore, requires immediate management.

C) CORRECT:

Thyroid lobectomy (hemithyroidectomy) is the preferred treatment for patients with well-differentiated intrathyroidal cancers < 1 cm without nodal or distant metastasis or high-risk features (patient age > 45 years, family history of cancer, and history of head or neck radiation). In these patients, hemithyroidectomy allows for definitive diagnosis (via histological analysis showing invasion of the basement membrane) and definitive management with a high probability of cure. Preservation of the contralateral lobe decreases the need for thyroid hormone replacement therapy and mitigates surgical risks associated with thyroidectomy (e.g., hypoparathyroidism).

In patients with intrathyroidal tumors > 4 cm, extrathyroidal spread, metastasis, or high-risk features, hemithyroidectomy is contraindicated and total thyroidectomy should be performed.

D) INCORRECT:

External beam radiation is used in residual or unresectable thyroid cancers with invasion into the adjacent structures (e.g., esophagus, trachea, great vessels). Well-differentiated thyroid cancers are generally not treated with external beam radiation because it is not as effective as radioiodine therapy and does not target thyroid tissue as selectively, posing a risk to nearby structures in the head and neck. Because this patient has no evidence of locally advanced disease and has not yet received a definitive diagnosis, external beam radiation is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

In TSH suppression therapy, synthetic T4 hormone (levothyroxine) is used to decrease TSH release from the pituitary via a negative feedback loop. TSH suppression reduces stimulation of malignant thyroid tissue and therefore decreases the probability of cancer growth. After initial surgical management, patients with follicular thyroid cancer may require thyroid hormone replacement therapy to prevent hypothyroidism and to minimize the risk of TSH stimulation of any residual tumor cells. However, thyroid hormone therapy is not used as initial therapy in patients with well-differentiated thyroid cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

Radioiodine therapy is an effective treatment option for well-differentiated thyroid cancers, as the malignant cells take up iodine, resulting in ablation. However, radioiodine therapy is an adjuvant treatment and is not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient. Radioablative therapy may be used later if there is reason to suspect remaining thyroid tissue.

G) INCORRECT:

Total thyroidectomy is an appropriate initial treatment option for patients with an intrathyroidal tumor > 1 cm, a tumor with extrathyroidal extension, and/or metastasis, or if the patient has high-risk features (age > 45 years, history of head or neck radiation, family history of cancer). While a total thyroidectomy would offer definitive management and is potentially curative for this patient, another treatment is preferred in this patient with a small (< 1 cm) intrathyroidal tumor.
questions.hint: In a hypoechoic thyroid nodule, the combination of neoplastic follicular cells on fine-needle aspiration (FNA) and a mutation in the RAS gene on molecular analysis should raise suspicion for follicular thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year old man comes to the physician because of a painless neck lump and a 2-month history of difficulty swallowing. He has a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis and episodic hypertension. Physical examination shows a 3 × 3-cm, nontender nodule at the level of the thyroid cartilage. A photomicrograph of a section of tissue obtained by core needle biopsy of the nodule is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Follicular carcinoma is the second most common type of thyroid cancer and typically manifests as an invasive tumor that spreads hematogenously. Histopathological features include cuboidal cells arranged spherically around colloid lakes, which are not seen in this case. Follicular carcinoma is not associated with MEN 2A.
Image Description:

Micrograph of a histological section of thyroid (H&E stain).

Multiple uniform follicles of similar sizes with an absence of papillary nuclear features. Additionally, these lesions must demonstrate capsular or vascular invasion.

This appearance is typical of a well differentiated follicular thyroid cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Anaplastic carcinoma is a rare malignancy that typically manifests with aggressive local growth and rapid lymphatic and hematogenous metastasis; it has the poorest prognosis of all thyroid cancers. Histopathological features include undifferentiated, pleiomorphic giant cells with areas of necrosis, hemorrhage, and nuclear atypia, which are not seen in this case. Anaplastic carcinoma is not associated with MEN 2A.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fine-needle aspiration from a thyroid lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Highly pleomorphic cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with enlarged, irregular nuclei that have prominent nucleoli (examples indicated by arrows) are visible. Multinucleated tumor cells (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can also be seen. There are no follicular or papillary growth patterns.

The diagnosis of an anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a diagnosis of exclusion. This patient's diagnosis was supported by immunohistochemical findings (negative for TTF-1, thyroglobulin, and calcitonin).

C) INCORRECT:

NHL of the thyroid gland is a rare malignancy that typically manifests with B symptoms (e.g., weight loss, night sweats, and fever) and a rapidly growing tumor that can lead to tracheal compression. Histopathological features include sheets of lymphocytes, which are not seen in this case. NHL is not associated with MEN 2A.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of ileum tissue (H&E staining; very high magnification) showing densely arranged poorly differentiated cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer but typically develops as a well-differentiated, slow-growing tumor with early lymphatic invasion. Histopathological features include psammoma bodies, Orphan Annie eye nuclei, and nuclear grooves, which are not seen in this case. Papillary thyroid carcinoma is sometimes caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene (which is also mutated in MEN 2).
Image Description:

Micrograph image of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

Arrowheads: examples of pathological nuclei
Blue overlay: connective tissue core of papillae
Yellow dashed overlay: epithelial cancer cells covering the papillae
Yellow overlay: psammoma bodies

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) CORRECT:

The photomicrograph shows sheets of polygonal cells surrounded by amyloid stroma, which confirms a diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma. This type of thyroid cancer is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (both MEN 2A and MEN 2B). MEN 2A can also manifest with primary hyperparathyroidism (which causes recurrent nephrolithiasis) and pheochromocytoma (which causes episodic hypertension).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

Green overlay: amyloid deposits
Red: exemplary tumor cells

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
questions.hint: This man's clinical presentation strongly indicates MEN 2A syndrome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of a painless lump on her neck. Examination shows a hard nodule on the left side of her neck. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy shows well-differentiated cuboidal cells arranged spherically around colloid. She undergoes thyroidectomy. Histopathological examination of the surgical specimen shows invasion of the thyroid capsule and blood vessels. Which of the following cellular events is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Activation mutation in the BRAF gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

TSH receptor (TSHR) gene mutations are associated with toxic thyroid adenoma and toxic multinodular goiter, which would both present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., irritability, tachycardia, fine tremor). On histopathology, toxic multinodular goiter shows variable-sized dilated follicles with hyperplastic epithelium, and areas of fibrosis, hemorrhage, and calcification. Vascular and capsular invasion would not be seen.

B) INCORRECT:

Activation mutation in the BRAF gene is associated with papillary thyroid cancer, the most common type of thyroid cancer. Histologically, papillary cancers are characterized by calcified spherules (psammoma bodies), large oval cells with empty-appearing nuclei (“Orphan Annie” eye nuclei), and nuclear grooves. Lymphatic invasion is more common in papillary cancers, as opposed to follicular thyroid cancer where capsular and vascular invasion is common.
Image Description:

Histopathology slide of the ovary (H&E stain)

In addition to papillary tumor cells, there are two Psammoma bodies located in the lower left corner of the image (red overlay). Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellar calcifications, which are characteristic for serous tumors of the ovary.

C) INCORRECT:

Mutations that cause inactivation of p53 tumor suppressor gene would be characteristic of anaplastic thyroid cancer, rather than follicular thyroid cancer. Anaplastic thyroid cancer is a rare but aggressive type of thyroid cancer that causes rapid local growth, with lymphatic and hematogenous metastasis. Histology usually reveals undifferentiated, pleomorphic giant cells, with areas of necrosis, hemorrhage, and significant nuclear atypia.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fine-needle aspiration from a thyroid lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Highly pleomorphic cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with enlarged, irregular nuclei that have prominent nucleoli (examples indicated by arrows) are visible. Multinucleated tumor cells (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can also be seen. There are no follicular or papillary growth patterns.

The diagnosis of an anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a diagnosis of exclusion. This patient's diagnosis was supported by immunohistochemical findings (negative for TTF-1, thyroglobulin, and calcitonin).

D) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the RET proto-oncogene are associated with medullary thyroid cancer, which is derived from calcitonin-producing parafollicular C cells, not from thyroid hormone-producing follicular cells. It presents with sheets of polygonal cells surrounded by amyloid stroma that stains with Congo red.

E) CORRECT:

PAX8-PPAR gamma gene rearrangement is involved in the pathogenesis of follicular thyroid adenoma and follicular thyroid cancer, the second most common type of thyroid cancer. Unlike benign thyroid adenomas, follicular thyroid cancer is more likely to cause early invasion of the thyroid capsule and vasculature, making it the most likely diagnosis here.

Follicular thyroid adenomas and follicular thyroid cancers are also associated with point mutations of the KRAS oncogene.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a thyroid tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

A partly encapsulated (capsule marked by hatched blue overlay) thyroid lesion comprised of follicles of varying size and shape (blue overlay) can be seen. Focally, this lesion displays a capsular invasion (yellow overlay), which is diagnostic of follicular thyroid carcinoma.
questions.hint: Cuboidal cells arranged spherically around colloid is a characteristic feature of thyroid follicles and follicular cells, indicating that this patient's thyroid nodule is a follicular tumor. Vascular and capsular invasion of the thyroid gland would be consistent with follicular thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a lump on her neck and a 1-week history of hoarseness. Examination shows a 3-cm, firm, nontender nodule on the anterior neck. Further evaluation confirms a thyroid malignancy, and she undergoes thyroidectomy. Histopathologic examination of the surgical specimen shows lymphatic invasion. Genetic analysis shows RET/PTC chromosomal rearrangement. Microscopic examination of the surgical specimen is most likely to also show which of the following?

choices.text: Pleomorphic giant cells with numerous atypical mitotic figures
Sheets of polygonal cells surrounding amyloid deposition
Calcified spherules and large oval cells with empty-appearing nuclei
Cuboidal cells arranged spherically around colloid lakes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pleomorphic giant cells with numerous atypical mitotic figures are seen in anaplastic thyroid cancer, as are areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. Anaplastic cancers are rare, but also the most aggressive thyroid cancers. This patient's genetic analysis is suggestive of papillary, rather than anaplastic thyroid cancer, which is sometimes associated with p53 inactivation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fine-needle aspiration from a thyroid lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Highly pleomorphic cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with enlarged, irregular nuclei that have prominent nucleoli (examples indicated by arrows) are visible. Multinucleated tumor cells (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can also be seen. There are no follicular or papillary growth patterns.

The diagnosis of an anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a diagnosis of exclusion. This patient's diagnosis was supported by immunohistochemical findings (negative for TTF-1, thyroglobulin, and calcitonin).

B) INCORRECT:

Sheets of polygonal cells surrounding amyloid deposition is characteristic of medullary thyroid cancer, which account for < 10% of all thyroid cancers. The amyloid deposits in the stroma stain with congo red. This patient's genetic analysis is suggestive of papillary, rather than medullary thyroid cancer, which is associated with RET mutations (MEN 2).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 300x magnification)

Green overlay: tumor cell nests
Black arrows: fibrous bands with prominent vascularity

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) CORRECT:

Calcified spherules (psammoma bodies) and large oval cells with empty-appearing nuclei (Orphan Annie eyes nuclei) would most likely be seen on histopathology of thyroid tissue from this patient. These features, along with nuclear grooves, are characteristic of papillary thyroid cancer, which accounts for ∼ 80% of all thyroid cancers and is typically a well-differentiated, slow-growing tumor. In contrast to follicular thyroid cancer, which spreads hematogenously, papillary thyroid cancers spread by early lymphatic invasion.
Image Description:

Micrograph image of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

Arrowheads: examples of pathological nuclei
Blue overlay: connective tissue core of papillae
Yellow dashed overlay: epithelial cancer cells covering the papillae
Yellow overlay: psammoma bodies

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Cuboidal cells arranged spherically around colloid lakes are characteristic of follicular thyroid cancer, which accounts for 8–10% of all thyroid cancers. This patient's genetic analysis is suggestive of papillary, rather than follicular thyroid cancer, which is associated with RAS mutation or PAX8-PPAR-γ rearrangement.
Image Description:

Micrograph of a histological section of thyroid (H&E stain).

Multiple uniform follicles of similar sizes with an absence of papillary nuclear features. Additionally, these lesions must demonstrate capsular or vascular invasion.

This appearance is typical of a well differentiated follicular thyroid cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperplastic epithelium with colloid scalloping can be seen in Graves disease. Although Graves disease can be a potentially dangerous condition of the thyroid, it is not a type of thyroid cancer. This patient's presentation and genetic analysis are suggestive of papillary thyroid cancer, which would have different histopathologic findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

Green overlay: papillary infoldings of hyperplastic thyroid follicles

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
questions.hint: RET/PTC rearrangement is often seen in papillary thyroid cancer and results in the production of a constitutively activated tyrosine kinase.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of a painless lump on his neck. Two years ago, he underwent surgery for treatment-resistant hypertension, episodic headaches, and palpitations. Physical examination shows a firm, irregular swelling on the right side of the neck. Ultrasonography of the thyroid gland shows a 2-cm nodule with irregular margins and microcalcifications in the right thyroid lobe. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show increased serum concentration of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular cells (C cells) that often arises sporadically but is also associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A and type 2B (MEN2). Since parafollicular cells produce the hormone calcitonin, increased serum calcitonin would be expected. Measuring the serum calcitonin concentration is helpful to support the diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma and is also used to monitor for residual disease or recurrence after thyroidectomy.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin would be seen in gastrinoma, which is a feature of MEN1, not MEN2. MEN1 would also manifest with primary hyperparathyroidism and/or pituitary adenomas, not with pheochromocytoma. Furthermore, gastrinomas are located mainly in the duodenum or pancreas and would therefore neither cause a swelling on the right side of the neck nor a nodule in the thyroid lobe. Finally, symptoms of gastrinoma such as treatment-resistant peptic ulcer disease and diarrhea are not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased serum metanephrines would be seen in pheochromocytoma, which is a feature of MEN2. However, the patient was already operated on for a pheochromocytoma, and the recent findings are consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma, which would not result in an increase in serum metanephrines.

D) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma does not lead to increased serum TSH. Increased serum TSH can be seen in primary hypothyroidism or central hyperthyroidism. However, this patient has no symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, constipation, fatigue) or hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, diarrhea, restlessness). Also, MEN2 is not commonly associated with dysfunction of the thyroid gland.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased serum PTH would indicate hyperparathyroidism, which is a feature of MEN2 A in 20–30% of cases. However, the patient shows no symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., nephrolithiasis, bone, muscle, and joint pain, peptic ulcer disease, or depression). Additionally, a firm, irregular thyroid nodule is more suggestive of a malignancy of the thyroid gland, which does not increase serum PTH.
questions.hint: This patient likely has a history of pheochromocytoma (treatment-resistant hypertension, episodic headaches, palpitations) that was treated with adrenalectomy. His painless, irregular thyroid nodule should raise concern for medullary thyroid carcinoma as a feature of MEN2 syndrome.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of a painless, progressively growing lump on her neck. She has no difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, or dyspnea. Past medical history is unremarkable. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 2-cm (0.8-in) nodule on the right side of her neck that moves with swallowing. Serum TSH concentration is 0.2 μU/mL. Ultrasound shows a 2.3-cm (0.91-in) hypoechoic mass in the right thyroid lobe. Thyroid scintigraphy reveals a nodule with decreased radiotracer uptake. Fine-needle aspiration cytology shows concentric lamellar calcifications, large oval nuclei with central clearing, and lymphocytic infiltration. Molecular genetic testing showed no BRAF mutations. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain histopathological features, such as vascular infiltration, are associated with a poor prognosis in patients with thyroid cancer, but lymphocytic infiltration is associated with a lower recurrence rate and reduced mortality.

B) INCORRECT:

Certain histopathological features in thyroid cancer, such as vascular infiltration, are associated with a poor prognosis. However, psammoma bodies simply indicate dystrophic calcification and are a defining feature of PTC. Among all histological variants of thyroid cancer, PTC generally has the best prognosis.

C) CORRECT:

The peak incidence of PTC is 30–50 years of age, and it generally has the best prognosis among all thyroid cancer variants. However, an older age at diagnosis is associated with a poor prognosis for papillary, follicular, and medullary thyroid cancers. The TNM staging system uses an age cutoff of ≥ 55 years to identify patients with a high risk of mortality from these cancers. Other factors indicating a poor prognosis include male sex, large tumor (i.e., > 4 cm), extrathyroidal growth, lymph node involvement with extranodal extension, multifocality, specific molecular characteristics (such as RAS and BRAF mutations), and certain histopathological features (e.g., tall cells, poor differentiation, and vascular infiltration).

D) INCORRECT:

PTC is more common in female than male individuals, but female individuals have a more favorable prognosis than male individuals.

E) INCORRECT:

Specific molecular characteristics, such as BRAF mutations, are associated with a higher risk of extrathyroidal extension, lymph node metastases, and distant metastases in PTC. The absence of BRAF mutations, on the other hand, is associated with a favorable prognosis.
questions.hint: Concentric lamellar calcifications (psammoma bodies) and large oval nuclei with central clearing (Orphan Annie eyes nuclei) are typical features of papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-month history of a painless lump on his neck. Two years ago, he underwent adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma. Physical examination shows a firm, irregular swelling on the right side of the neck. Ultrasonography of the thyroid gland shows a 2-cm nodule with irregular margins and microcalcifications in the right thyroid lobe. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show increased serum concentration of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular cells (C cells) that often arises sporadically but is also associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A and type 2B (MEN2). Since parafollicular cells produce the hormone calcitonin, increased serum calcitonin would be expected. Measuring the serum calcitonin concentration is helpful to support the diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma and is also used to monitor for residual disease or recurrence after thyroidectomy.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin would be seen in gastrinoma, which is a feature of MEN1, not MEN2. MEN1 would also manifest with primary hyperparathyroidism and/or pituitary adenomas, not with pheochromocytoma. Furthermore, gastrinomas are located mainly in the duodenum or pancreas and would therefore neither cause a swelling on the right side of the neck nor a nodule in the thyroid lobe. Finally, symptoms of gastrinoma such as treatment-resistant peptic ulcer disease and diarrhea are not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased serum metanephrines would be seen in pheochromocytoma, which is a feature of MEN2. However, the patient was already operated on for a pheochromocytoma, and the recent findings are consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma, which would not result in an increase in serum metanephrines.

D) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma does not lead to increased serum TSH. Increased serum TSH can be seen in primary hypothyroidism or central hyperthyroidism. However, this patient has no symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, constipation, fatigue) or hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, diarrhea, restlessness). Also, MEN2 is not commonly associated with dysfunction of the thyroid gland.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased serum PTH would indicate hyperparathyroidism, which is a feature of MEN2 A in 20–30% of cases. However, the patient shows no symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., nephrolithiasis, bone, muscle, and joint pain, peptic ulcer disease, or depression). Additionally, a firm, irregular thyroid nodule is more suggestive of a malignancy of the thyroid gland, which does not increase serum PTH.
questions.hint: His painless, irregular thyroid nodule should raise concern for medullary thyroid carcinoma as a feature of MEN2 syndrome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office because of a small lump on the right side of her neck that she noticed while putting lotion on 1 week ago. She has not had any weight change, palpitations, or altered bowel habits. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last for 4 days. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Examination shows a small nodule on the right side of the neck that moves with swallowing. There is no lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is most likely to be helpful in determining the next step in management?

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the swelling

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy is indicated when malignancy is suspected in a thyroid nodule. Another step in management is indicated at this time to help determine the necessity of an FNA.

B) INCORRECT:

An open biopsy can be used to remove the complete thyroid nodule or to obtain a better sample if fine-needle aspiration biopsy fails to provide clear results (e.g., because of an insufficient sample size). An open biopsy is not the most appropriate initial assessment.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy allows for classification of thyroid nodules based on the amount of radiotracer a nodule absorbs and is able to distinguish between hot and cold nodules. Although thyroid scintigraphy may be performed in the workup of thyroid nodules, a more basic functional assessment of the thyroid gland should be conducted first.

A hot or hyperfunctioning nodule contains thyroid hormone-producing cells and could result in hyperthyroidism, whereas a cold or nonfunctional nodule lacks thyroid hormone-producing cells and may indicate malignant neoplasia.

D) CORRECT:

Measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) serum concentration and thyroid ultrasound should be performed in all patients with a suspected thyroid nodule to determine further management. If TSH levels are normal or elevated, this patient should undergo regular monitoring in case the tumor grows to ≥ 1 cm, in which case fine-needle aspiration biopsy would be indicated because of her suspicious ultrasound findings. If TSH levels are subnormal, she should be evaluated for hyperthyroidism with thyroid scintigraphy.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

E) INCORRECT:

Although a CT scan of the neck is recommended for the staging of confirmed thyroid cancer, it is not suitable for the initial evaluation of patients with a thyroid nodule.
questions.hint: Thyroid function has not yet been assessed in this patient.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of a hard, painless lump on her neck that has gradually increased in size. She recalls undergoing radiation therapy to the head and neck region during childhood for a benign condition. Family history is unremarkable. Examination shows a 2.5-cm (1-in) firm, irregular swelling on the left side of the neck that moves with swallowing. There is painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Ultrasonography of the neck shows a solitary left lobe thyroid mass with increased vascularity and hyperechogenic punctate regions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Follicular carcinoma is the second most common type of thyroid cancer (10% of all cases) with a peak incidence of 40–60 years of age. Follicular carcinoma is unique in that it spreads predominantly via the bloodstream to the lungs and bones. In this patient with cervical lymphadenopathy, a different type of thyroid cancer that metastasizes to the lymph nodes and is linked to radiation exposure during childhood is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Medullary carcinoma is a rare type of cancer (< 10% of all thyroid cancers) that is more likely to occur in individuals 50–60 years of age or in association with MEN II syndromes. This patient is 36 years old, has palpable lymph nodes, and a negative family history, which all suggest a more common type of thyroid cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Hurthle cell carcinomas are relatively rare tumors of the thyroid (3% of all cases) that are most likely to occur in patients between 50–60 years of age. Hurthle cell carcinoma mainly spreads hematogenously, although lymph node metastasis is not uncommon. The most likely diagnosis in this 36-year-old patient with painless cervical lymphadenopathy is a more common thyroid cancer that spreads to the lymph nodes.

D) CORRECT:

Papillary thyroid carcinomas are the most common type of thyroid cancer (∼ 80% of cases) and have a peak incidence between 30–50 years of age. These carcinomas commonly manifest with early lymphatic spread. Patients often present with painless cervical lymphadenopathy that may be detectable before the primary tumor. The hyperechogenic punctate regions seen on this patient's ultrasound likely represent microcalcifications, another characteristic feature of this type of thyroid cancer. Based on the overall incidence rate, affected age group, history of radiation therapy during childhood, and metastatic pattern, papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

See “Characteristic features of thyroid cancer” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Anaplastic carcinoma is a rare and highly aggressive cancer of the thyroid (1–2% of cases) that typically spreads early via the lymphatic system, which could explain the new-onset lymphadenopathy in this patient. However, anaplastic carcinoma typically affects patients older than 60 years of age. In this 36-year-old patient with a relatively slow-growing thyroid mass, another type of thyroid cancer is more likely.
questions.hint: A thyroid mass with features of malignancy (increased vascularity and hyperechogenic punctate areas), painless cervical lymphadenopathy, and a history of childhood radiation therapy should raise concern for a thyroid malignancy linked to ionizing radiation exposure.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a palpable thyroid nodule discovered incidentally on routine imaging. She has no significant medical history, family history of thyroid cancer, or previous radiation exposure. She reports no compressive symptoms and has stable weight with normal energy levels. On examination, a 2-cm nodule is palpated in the right thyroid lobe. Serum TSH is within the normal range (see reports).

Ultrasound: Well-circumscribed nodule with no suspicious lymphadenopathy
Fine needle aspiration cytology: Follicular neoplasm (Bethesda category IV)

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Follicular neoplasms identified on fine needle aspiration cytology cannot be definitively classified as benign or malignant because cytology does not assess for capsular or vascular invasion, which are hallmarks of follicular carcinoma. A thyroid lobectomy provides the necessary tissue for histopathologic evaluation to establish a definitive diagnosis. This approach allows examination of the nodule while preserving the contralateral lobe. If malignancy is confirmed, further management can be tailored accordingly. This practice aligns with current guidelines for managing thyroid nodules classified as Bethesda category IV.

Key learning point: For a thyroid nodule classified as a follicular neoplasm (Bethesda category 4), hemithyroidectomy is the recommended management to obtain a definitive histological diagnosis and assess for malignancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Serial ultrasound imaging might be considered for nodules that appear benign or stable. However, a follicular neoplasm (Bethesda category IV) requires histologic evaluation to assess for capsular or vascular invasion. The nodule's size and intermediate risk necessitate a more definitive diagnostic approach than observation, as waiting could delay necessary surgical evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Total thyroidectomy may be considered if there is evidence of multifocal disease, family history of thyroid cancer, or previous radiation exposure. In this patient, the solitary, well-circumscribed nodule without high-risk features or lymph node abnormalities suggests a diagnostic lobectomy is more appropriate. This approach minimizes surgical morbidity and avoids unnecessary lifelong hormone supplementation if the lesion is benign.

D) INCORRECT:

TSH suppression therapy is used for benign thyroid nodules to reduce size by lowering TSH. However, in a follicular neoplasm (Bethesda category IV), the primary concern is excluding malignancy, which requires histopathological evaluation. TSH suppression does not provide tissue for evaluation or alter the course of a potentially malignant process, delaying necessary surgical intervention.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman is evaluated in the Outpatient Clinic for a firm thyroid nodule. She has a family history of thyroid cancer, and her father died from medullary thyroid carcinoma. Fine-needle aspiration confirms medullary thyroid carcinoma. Neck ultrasound reveals a 2.5-cm nodule in the right thyroid lobe and a suspected 1-cm lesion in the left lobe. Genetic testing shows a germline RET proto-oncogene mutation. She is clinically euthyroid with normal TSH (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Serum calcitonin
700 ng/L
< 10 ng/L


CT scan: No evidence of distant metastases
What is the most appropriate surgical procedure?

choices.text: Subtotal thyroidectomy sparing portions of both lobes
Total thyroidectomy with prophylactic central neck dissection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Right thyroid lobectomy alone is insufficient for medullary thyroid carcinoma in the presence of a germline RET mutation and family history, which suggest bilateral and multifocal disease. The suspected lesion in the left lobe and the risk of bilateral involvement necessitate a more comprehensive surgical approach to ensure complete disease management.

B) INCORRECT:

Subtotal thyroidectomy is inadequate for medullary thyroid carcinoma, especially with a germline RET mutation and family history. The diffuse distribution of parafollicular C cells predisposes to multifocal and bilateral disease. Retaining thyroid tissue increases the risk of persistent disease and recurrence, making total thyroidectomy necessary.

C) CORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) arises from parafollicular C cells and is often associated with germline RET proto-oncogene mutations in familial cases. In patients with confirmed RET mutations and evidence of disease in one lobe with suspected contralateral involvement, total thyroidectomy is indicated to remove all potential tumor foci. Prophylactic central neck dissection is warranted due to the high risk of early lymphatic spread in MTC, addressing microscopic nodal metastases not evident on imaging. Elevated serum calcitonin supports the diagnosis and the need for aggressive surgical management to reduce recurrence risk.

Key learning point: Total thyroidectomy is the recommended surgical procedure for medullary thyroid cancer to ensure complete removal of cancerous tissue and allow for effective postoperative monitoring.

D) INCORRECT:

Radioactive iodine treatment is ineffective for medullary thyroid carcinoma, as parafollicular C cells do not uptake iodine. The management of MTC relies on complete surgical resection. The elevated calcitonin level and RET mutation confirm the diagnosis, and the absence of distant metastases emphasizes the need for surgical intervention.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman undergoes an ultrasound for neck pain and is incidentally found to have a 0.9-cm thyroid nodule in the right lobe. She has no known history of hormonal disorders, and her family history is unremarkable. On palpation, the thyroid gland is nontender with no palpable lymph nodes. She reports no compressive symptoms, and her physical examination remains stable over several months. She expresses anxiety about possible complications if treated aggressively (see lab result and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.0 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L



Ultrasound: 0.9-cm thyroid nodule in the right lobe; no extrathyroidal extension or suspicious lymph nodes
Fine-needle aspiration biopsy: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Lobectomy followed by radioactive iodine ablation
Immediate total thyroidectomy with prophylactic central neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy and TSH suppression therapy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Papillary thyroid microcarcinomas, particularly those less than 1 cm without extrathyroidal extension or lymph node involvement, often follow an indolent course. The absence of compressive symptoms, a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level, and stable physical findings support a conservative management approach. Current guidelines recommend active surveillance in low-risk cases to minimize morbidity associated with thyroid surgery. Regular ultrasound monitoring allows for timely detection of changes in nodule size or characteristics, ensuring intervention if the tumor progresses.

Key learning point: For small, low-risk papillary thyroid microcarcinomas (<1 cm) without aggressive features, active surveillance or follow-up is often the recommended management strategy.

B) INCORRECT:

Radioactive iodine (RAI) ablation is typically used after total thyroidectomy in high-risk papillary thyroid carcinoma. In this case, the 0.9-cm nodule is low-risk, confined to one lobe, and lacks aggressive features. Intact thyroid tissue after lobectomy would limit RAI effectiveness, as normal thyroid tissue would sequester iodine. The patient's low-risk profile and concerns about overtreatment support a less aggressive approach.

C) INCORRECT:

Total thyroidectomy with prophylactic central neck dissection is recommended for papillary thyroid carcinomas with high-risk features, such as multifocal disease or lymphadenopathy. This patient's tumor is 0.9 cm, confined to a single lobe, with no extrathyroidal extension or lymph node involvement. The risks of central neck dissection, including recurrent laryngeal nerve injury and hypoparathyroidism, make it suitable only for higher-risk cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Total thyroidectomy with thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) suppression therapy is reserved for higher-risk papillary thyroid carcinomas, such as those >1 cm or with extrathyroidal extension. This patient's 0.9-cm lesion lacks aggressive features and lymphadenopathy, indicating a very low-risk tumor. Aggressive treatment increases surgical risks and complications without significant benefit. TSH suppression therapy can adversely affect bone density and cardiac function when used inappropriately.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of a painless lump on his neck. He underwent adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma two years ago. On examination, there is a firm, irregular swelling on the right side of his neck. Ultrasonography of the thyroid gland reveals a 2-cm nodule with irregular margins and microcalcifications in the right thyroid lobe. Further evaluation is most likely to show an increased serum concentration of which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular cells (C cells) that often arises sporadically but is also associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A and type 2B (MEN2). Since parafollicular cells produce the hormone calcitonin, increased serum calcitonin would be expected. Measuring the serum calcitonin concentration is helpful to support the diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma and is also used to monitor for residual disease or recurrence after thyroidectomy.

Key learning point: Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells and is characterized by elevated serum calcitonin, serving as a key tumor marker for diagnosis and monitoring.

B) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma does not lead to increased serum TSH. Increased serum TSH can be seen in primary hypothyroidism or central hyperthyroidism. However, this patient has no symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, constipation, fatigue) or hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, diarrhea, restlessness). Also, MEN2 is not commonly associated with dysfunction of the thyroid gland.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased serum PTH would indicate hyperparathyroidism, which is a feature of MEN2 A in 20–30% of cases. However, the patient shows no symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., nephrolithiasis, bone, muscle, and joint pain, peptic ulcer disease, or depression). Additionally, a firm, irregular thyroid nodule is more suggestive of a malignancy of the thyroid gland, which does not increase serum PTH.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin would be seen in gastrinoma, which is a feature of MEN1, not MEN2. MEN1 would also manifest with primary hyperparathyroidism and/or pituitary adenomas, not with pheochromocytoma. Furthermore, gastrinomas are located mainly in the duodenum or pancreas and would therefore neither cause a swelling on the right side of the neck nor a nodule in the thyroid lobe. Finally, symptoms of gastrinoma such as treatment-resistant peptic ulcer disease and diarrhea are not seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased serum metanephrines would be seen in pheochromocytoma, which is a feature of MEN2. However, the patient was already operated on for a pheochromocytoma, and the recent findings are consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma, which would not result in an increase in serum metanephrines.
questions.hint: His painless, irregular thyroid nodule should raise concern for medullary thyroid carcinoma as a feature of MEN2 syndrome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to your clinic because she noticed a small lump on the right side of her neck while applying lotion 1 week ago. She has not experienced any weight change, palpitations, or changes in bowel habits. Her menstrual cycles are regular every 30 days and last 4 days. Her temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. On examination, there is a small nodule on the right side of her neck that moves with swallowing. There is no lymphadenopathy. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the swelling.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy is indicated when malignancy is suspected in a thyroid nodule. Another step in management is indicated at this time to help determine the necessity of an FNA.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy allows for classification of thyroid nodules based on the amount of radiotracer a nodule absorbs and is able to distinguish between hot and cold nodules. Although thyroid scintigraphy may be performed in the workup of thyroid nodules, a more basic functional assessment of the thyroid gland should be conducted first.

A hot or hyperfunctioning nodule contains thyroid hormone-producing cells and could result in hyperthyroidism, whereas a cold or nonfunctional nodule lacks thyroid hormone-producing cells and may indicate malignant neoplasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a CT scan of the neck is recommended for the staging of confirmed thyroid cancer, it is not suitable for the initial evaluation of patients with a thyroid nodule.

D) CORRECT:

Measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) serum concentration and thyroid ultrasound should be performed in all patients with a suspected thyroid nodule to determine further management. If TSH levels are normal or elevated, this patient should undergo regular monitoring in case the tumor grows to ≥ 1 cm, in which case fine-needle aspiration biopsy would be indicated because of her suspicious ultrasound findings. If TSH levels are subnormal, she should be evaluated for hyperthyroidism with thyroid scintigraphy.

Key learning point: The initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule should include measurement of serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) to guide further diagnostic steps.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

E) INCORRECT:

An open biopsy can be used to remove the complete thyroid nodule or to obtain a better sample if fine-needle aspiration biopsy fails to provide clear results (e.g., because of an insufficient sample size). An open biopsy is not the most appropriate initial assessment.
questions.hint: Thyroid function has not yet been assessed in this patient.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of a hard, painless lump on her neck that has gradually increased in size. She reports a history of radiation therapy to the head and neck region during childhood for a benign condition. There is no significant family history. On examination, you find a 2.5-cm firm, irregular swelling on the left side of her neck that moves with swallowing, along with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Neck ultrasonography reveals a solitary left lobe thyroid mass with increased vascularity and hyperechogenic punctate regions. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Papillary thyroid carcinomas are the most common type of thyroid cancer (∼ 80% of cases) and have a peak incidence between 30–50 years of age. These carcinomas commonly manifest with early lymphatic spread. Patients often present with painless cervical lymphadenopathy that may be detectable before the primary tumor. The hyperechogenic punctate regions seen on this patient's ultrasound likely represent microcalcifications, another characteristic feature of this type of thyroid cancer. Based on the overall incidence rate, affected age group, history of radiation therapy during childhood, and metastatic pattern, papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

See “Characteristic features of thyroid cancer” table.

Key learning point: Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid cancer, often linked to prior radiation exposure and characterized by early lymphatic spread and microcalcifications on imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Follicular carcinoma is the second most common type of thyroid cancer (10% of all cases) with a peak incidence of 40–60 years of age. Follicular carcinoma is unique in that it spreads predominantly via the bloodstream to the lungs and bones. In this patient with cervical lymphadenopathy, a different type of thyroid cancer that metastasizes to the lymph nodes and is linked to radiation exposure during childhood is more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Medullary carcinoma is a rare type of cancer (< 10% of all thyroid cancers) that is more likely to occur in individuals 50–60 years of age or in association with MEN II syndromes. This patient is 36 years old, has palpable lymph nodes, and a negative family history, which all suggest a more common type of thyroid cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Hurthle cell carcinomas are relatively rare tumors of the thyroid (3% of all cases) that are most likely to occur in patients between 50–60 years of age. Hurthle cell carcinoma mainly spreads hematogenously, although lymph node metastasis is not uncommon. The most likely diagnosis in this 36-year-old patient with painless cervical lymphadenopathy is a more common thyroid cancer that spreads to the lymph nodes.

E) INCORRECT:

Anaplastic carcinoma is a rare and highly aggressive cancer of the thyroid (1–2% of cases) that typically spreads early via the lymphatic system, which could explain the new-onset lymphadenopathy in this patient. However, anaplastic carcinoma typically affects patients older than 60 years of age. In this 36-year-old patient with a relatively slow-growing thyroid mass, another type of thyroid cancer is more likely.
questions.hint: A thyroid mass with features of malignancy (increased vascularity and hyperechogenic punctate areas), painless cervical lymphadenopathy, and a history of childhood radiation therapy should raise concern for a thyroid malignancy linked to ionizing radiation exposure.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with new hoarseness and a several-month history of neck discomfort. Physical examination reveals a 3-cm right thyroid nodule that is firm and does not move with swallowing. She has enlarged, nontender right cervical lymph nodes. Thyroid-stimulating hormone levels are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroglossal duct cysts typically manifest as midline neck masses that move with swallowing and tongue protrusion. This patient has a fixed lateral thyroid mass with associated lymphadenopathy, which is inconsistent with a thyroglossal duct cyst.

B) INCORRECT:

Toxic multinodular goiter typically manifests with hyperthyroid symptoms and reduced levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). This patient has normal TSH levels, and the fixed nature of the singular nodule with lymphadenopathy suggests malignancy rather than a benign hyperfunctioning process.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of a fixed thyroid nodule, voice changes, and painless cervical lymphadenopathy is highly suggestive of thyroid cancer. A fixed nodule that does not move while swallowing indicates infiltration into adjacent tissue. The recent onset of hoarseness suggests vocal cord paresis from cancer infiltration, and painless cervical lymphadenopathy can indicate lymphatic spread.

D) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis typically causes diffuse thyroid enlargement rather than a discrete nodule. While Hashimoto thyroiditis can manifest with neck discomfort, the fixed nodule and cervical lymphadenopathy are more consistent with malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Follicular adenomas are benign thyroid nodules that are not typically associated with voice changes or cervical lymphadenopathy. The fixed nature of this patient's nodule and associated symptoms suggest malignant rather than benign pathology.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents three days after total thyroidectomy with muscle cramping and perioral numbness. Vital signs are normal. Laboratory studies show serum calcium of 7.1 mg/dL. What is the most likely cause of her presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Postoperative hematoma would typically present with neck swelling, pain, and potentially respiratory compromise rather than the biochemical abnormality and neuromuscular symptoms seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury would manifest as voice changes and hoarseness rather than hypocalcemia and the associated neuromuscular symptoms described.

C) INCORRECT:

Residual thyroid tissue would not cause hypocalcemia. Any remaining thyroid tissue would more likely contribute to hyperthyroid symptoms rather than the calcium abnormality presented.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical site infection would typically present with local signs of inflammation, fever, and systemic symptoms rather than isolated hypocalcemia with neuromuscular manifestations.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Hypocalcemia following thyroidectomy results from accidental removal of parathyroid glands during surgery. The parathyroid glands are small and located at the back of the thyroid gland at variable locations, making complete preservation technically challenging. Accidental removal leads to hypoparathyroidism and explains the resulting hypocalcemia with associated neuromuscular manifestations.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a painless neck mass. She also reports a 6-month history of intermittent diarrhea and facial flushing. A fine-needle aspiration of a solitary thyroid nodule reveals spindle-shaped cells with granular cytoplasm and amyloid deposits, consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma. Elevation of which of the following serum markers is most specific for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a non-specific tumor marker that can be elevated in medullary thyroid carcinoma, as well as in various other malignancies like colorectal cancer. While CEA levels often correlate with tumor burden in MTC and can be useful for prognostication and monitoring alongside calcitonin, it lacks the specificity required to be the primary diagnostic marker for this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroglobulin is a protein produced by thyroid follicular cells and is a precursor to thyroid hormones. It is an excellent tumor marker for differentiated thyroid cancers, such as papillary and follicular carcinoma, which arise from these cells. However, medullary thyroid carcinoma originates from parafollicular cells, which do not produce thyroglobulin.

C) CORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor arising from the parafollicular cells of the thyroid, which are responsible for producing calcitonin. Malignant proliferation of these cells leads to excessive calcitonin secretion, making it the most specific and sensitive tumor marker for MTC. Elevated calcitonin levels are not only diagnostic but are also used to monitor for disease recurrence after thyroidectomy. The patient's chronic diarrhea is a classic paraneoplastic symptom caused by the secretagogue effect of high calcitonin levels on the gastrointestinal tract.

D) INCORRECT:

Chromogranin A is a general marker for neuroendocrine tumors, and medullary thyroid carcinoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor. While it may be elevated in this patient, it is not specific, as it can also be elevated in carcinoid tumors, pheochromocytomas, and other neuroendocrine neoplasms.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is a pituitary hormone used to assess the functional status of the thyroid gland, and it is the initial test in the workup of a thyroid nodule. However, it is not a tumor marker for thyroid cancer. Most patients with thyroid cancer, including medullary thyroid carcinoma, are euthyroid and have a normal TSH level.
questions.hint: This patient's cancer originates from the parafollicular cells of the thyroid.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a painless lump in her neck that she discovered three months ago. She has no associated symptoms of dysphagia, hoarseness, or weight change. Her medical history is significant for radiation therapy to the neck for childhood lymphoma. On physical examination, there is a 2-cm, firm, non-tender nodule in the right lobe of the thyroid that moves with swallowing. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a normal TSH level. A thyroid ultrasound reveals a solid, hypoechoic nodule with irregular margins and microcalcifications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from parafollicular C-cells and is less common. While it presents as a thyroid nodule, it is not associated with radiation exposure. It is often linked with MEN 2 syndromes and would typically have an elevated serum calcitonin level. The ultrasound may show a solid, hypoechoic mass, but often with coarse calcifications rather than the microcalcifications seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune condition that typically causes diffuse goiter and hypothyroidism, although patients can be euthyroid. While nodules can occur within a gland affected by Hashimoto thyroiditis, the classic ultrasound appearance is diffuse hypoechogenicity and parenchymal inhomogeneity, not a discrete nodule with high-risk features like irregular margins and microcalcifications.

C) INCORRECT:

A colloid nodule is a benign finding and the most common cause of a thyroid nodule. It manifests as a painless mass in a euthyroid patient. However, on ultrasound, colloid nodules are typically well-defined, isoechoic or hyperechoic and may have cystic or spongiform changes, not irregular margins or microcalcifications.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC), the most common type of thyroid cancer. Clinically, most thyroid cancers present as a painless, palpable nodule in a euthyroid patient, as seen here with the normal TSH. The ultrasound findings are highly suspicious for malignancy and characteristic of PTC: a solid, hypoechoic nodule with irregular margins and microcalcifications. These microcalcifications represent psammoma bodies on histology, a hallmark of PTC. Although prognosis is generally excellent, management typically involves surgical resection followed by radioactive iodine therapy and TSH suppression, depending on the stage.

E) INCORRECT:

A follicular thyroid carcinoma can manifest as a solitary, painless thyroid nodule in a euthyroid patient. However, it is less strongly associated with prior radiation exposure than the most common type of thyroid cancer. Furthermore, follicular neoplasms often appear as solid, encapsulated masses on ultrasound.
questions.hint: The history of childhood radiation exposure is the most significant risk factor for developing this condition.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman presents with a slowly enlarging mass on the right side of her neck over 2 months to the clinic. She has no significant medical history. Examination reveals a firm nodule in the right thyroid lobe and a mobile, nontender lymph node in the right lateral cervical region. Neck ultrasound shows a 2-cm solid lesion in the right thyroid lobe with microcalcifications and a 1-cm lateral cervical lymph node displaying cystic areas. Thyroid function tests are within normal limits (see report).
Fine-needle aspiration of the lymph node: Follicular cells
Which of the following diagnoses best explains these fine-needle aspiration findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in cervical lymph nodes shows cytologic features like keratinization and intercellular bridges, not follicular cells. The ultrasound findings and patient profile are more consistent with thyroid carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma originates from parafollicular C cells and shows neuroendocrine features, such as plasmacytoid cells and amyloid deposition, not follicular cells. The FNA findings of follicular cells and the ultrasound features are inconsistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma.

C) CORRECT:

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is common in young to middle-aged women and often presents with a thyroid nodule with microcalcifications, indicative of psammoma bodies. It spreads via lymphatics, explaining the cystic degeneration in the cervical lymph node. Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of metastatic sites may show follicular cells, aligning with the findings here. The ultrasound and cytologic features support this diagnosis.

Key learning point: Cystic changes in cervical lymph nodes with follicular thyroid cells on fine needle aspiration are indicative of metastatic thyroid cancer, particularly papillary thyroid carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid lymphoma usually presents with a rapidly enlarging mass and compressive symptoms, often in older patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. FNA typically shows lymphoid cells, not follicular cells. The ultrasound features and cytology are more indicative of thyroid carcinoma.
